The three gunasSattva, Rajas, and Tamasare responsible for the creation of all beings and the performance of all actions. Understanding this is essential for liberation. The person who is affected by Rajas is driven by desires and passion, while the person in Sattva is calm and detached. The Tamasic person is deluded and confused in their actions. When one acts with a pure mind, without selfish desires, in accordance with the higher truth, they achieve the state of liberation. The fruits of actionwhether good or badare experienced by the doer based on the nature of their actions and desires. Those who are attached to worldly desires will be reborn, while those who perform selfless actions are liberated from the cycle of birth and death. The person who acts without attachment and with a spirit of renunciation, who seeks knowledge, performs their duties with devotion, and leads a life of selfless service, attains liberation. The mind, when influenced by the three gunas, can either lead one towards bondage or liberation. By understanding the nature of these gunas, one can transcend them. The threefold division of faithbased on Sattva, Rajas, and Tamasdetermines the type of worship one follows and the manner in which one practices their spiritual duties. A person who is free from attachment to the fruits of their actions, who is steadfast in their devotion to the Supreme, and who lives in accordance with the divine will, experiences the peace of liberation. Selfless action, performed with the right attitude and in the service of others, is the highest path to liberation and spiritual advancement. One who has transcended the three gunas and is unaffected by worldly desires is free from suffering and attains the ultimate state of liberation. The soul is eternal, unaffected by birth, death, or the actions of the body. The Supreme Soul is the ultimate reality, and by meditating upon this truth, one can attain liberation. One who performs actions with the understanding that they are performing the will of the Supreme, and who is unaffected by the fruits of those actions, attains the highest state of spiritual realization. The highest form of renunciation is the renunciation of attachment and desire, not the renunciation of action itself. True renunciation involves acting without desire for the fruits. By renouncing selfish desires and performing one's duties in a selfless manner, one can achieve liberation and transcend the cycle of birth and death. Actions performed with a sense of duty and detachment, guided by knowledge and wisdom, lead to liberation. Those who have attained the highest state of self-realization, who live in accordance with the divine will, are liberated and free from the bondage of material existence. By following the path of selfless action, one attains the Supreme and experiences the ultimate state of peace and bliss. The highest path to liberation is the path of knowledge, where one sees the divine in all beings, without attachment or selfish desire. All actions, whether good or bad, are ultimately governed by the three gunas. By transcending the gunas, one attains liberation. The person who is free from attachment and performs actions in accordance with the divine will is liberated and attains the highest state of spiritual realization. The person who has transcended the three gunas, who acts selflessly and lives in accordance with the supreme truth, attains liberation. By understanding the nature of the soul and the Supreme, and by performing selfless actions, one can transcend the limitations of the material world and attain the state of liberation. Selfless service, devotion to the Supreme, and the renunciation of selfish desires are the paths to spiritual freedom and liberation. One who performs actions with a sense of duty, without attachment to the fruits, attains liberation and becomes free from the cycle of birth and death. The Supreme Self is eternal, beyond the three gunas. By meditating on the Supreme and transcending the three gunas, one attains liberation. One who has transcended the gunas and performs actions in accordance with the Supreme will, without selfish desires, attains the ultimate state of liberation. The person who performs actions in the service of others, with humility and devotion, attains the highest state of spiritual realization. One who performs selfless actions, guided by wisdom and compassion, becomes free from the limitations of the material world and attains liberation. By renouncing attachment to the results of actions and performing them for the greater good, one attains the highest state of spiritual freedom. Through wisdom, devotion, and selfless service, one can overcome the limitations of the material world and attain the ultimate state of liberation. The soul is eternal, unchanging, and unaffected by the actions of the body. By meditating on this truth, one attains liberation. By performing actions with a sense of duty and detachment, one can transcend the influence of the three gunas and attain the highest state of liberation. The one who has attained the highest state of self-realization, who lives in accordance with the divine will, becomes free from the cycle of birth and death. By following the path of selfless action and devotion to the Supreme, one transcends the limitations of the material world and attains liberation. The Supreme is beyond the three gunas, and by meditating on the Supreme and performing actions in accordance with the divine will, one attains the state of liberation. By transcending the three gunas and performing actions selflessly, one attains liberation and becomes one with the Supreme. By constantly meditating on the Supreme and performing selfless actions, one transcends the gunas and attains the ultimate state of liberation. Selfless actions, performed with devotion and detachment, lead to the highest state of spiritual freedom and liberation. The one who has transcended the three gunas and is devoted to the Supreme attains liberation and becomes one with the eternal truth. By meditating on the Supreme and performing actions selflessly, one attains the highest state of spiritual realization. By surrendering all actions to the Supreme and acting selflessly, one transcends the gunas and attains the ultimate state of liberation. Thus, having heard this teaching, let the one who is free from attachment act according to the divine will. Do not be attached to the results of actions and perform them for the sake of others. This will lead to the highest state of liberation. Through wisdom, devotion, and selfless service, one can overcome the cycle of birth and death and attain the ultimate liberation. By transcending the influence of the gunas and acting selflessly, one attains the supreme state of liberation and becomes one with the eternal truth. The one who performs actions in service to others, with devotion and humility, attains the highest state of spiritual realization. One who has overcome the gunas and transcended the limitations of the material world becomes one with the Supreme and attains liberation. By living according to the divine will and performing selfless actions, one attains the ultimate state of liberation. Thus, the path of selfless action, devotion, and renunciation leads one to the supreme truth and liberation from the cycle of birth and death. By living in harmony with the divine will and transcending the three gunas, one attains the highest state of liberation. The one who is devoted to the Supreme, who lives in accordance with the divine will, and who performs selfless actions attains liberation. Thus, the highest state of liberation is attained through selfless action, devotion, and the renunciation of selfish desires. One who is devoted to the Supreme, and who acts with humility and selflessness, attains the ultimate state of liberation and spiritual freedom. By meditating on the Supreme and surrendering all actions to the divine will, one attains the highest state of liberation. Through selfless service, devotion, and detachment, one transcends the limitations of the material world and attains the ultimate liberation. The one who is devoted to the Supreme and who acts with a sense of duty and selflessness attains the highest state of spiritual freedom. Thus, by following the path of selfless action, devotion, and renunciation, one attains liberation and becomes one with the Supreme.
